Elephants can tell how much of something is in a closed bucket by smell alone. (Harkin)
Thomas Jefferson cut his Bible to pieces and glued it back together in the order he thought it should be written. (Ptaszynski)
In 19th century America, caviar was a free bar snack. (Murray)

Wrestling star André the Giant was so massive that once when he drunkenly passed out in a hotel lobby, staff couldn't move him and had to cordon him off with velvet ropes until he woke up. (Schreiber)
Using too much red lipstick can make your urine turn red. (Harkin)

To honour the US Supreme Court judge Antonin Scalia, Virginia George Mason's school of law renamed itself Antonin Scalia School of Law, then immediately renamed itself after it was pointed out that the acronym would be ASSoL. (Schreiber)
In Japan you can buy left-handed chopsticks. (Harkin)

A boatload of researchers are about to deliberately get themselves stuck in the Arctic ice for a year. (Ptaszynski)
Leo Tolstoy, one of the greatest writers of all time, frequently wore two hats in case his head got cold. (Murray)
One of the women about to take part in the first all-female spacewalk has spent the last eight years hand-rearing a flock of geese. (Ptaszynski)
The Netherlands has a restaurant where if you move tables there is a chance you'll end up in Belgium. (Murray)
In order to stop drought an Indian village married two frogs. Two months later they had to be divorced because it wouldn't stop raining. (Schreiber)
Sainsbury's sells triple-cooked chips which you then have to cook. (Harkin)
Greta Thunberg's middle name is Tintin. (Harkin)
You can now be pulled over for drink-driving by your own car. (Murray)
In a country of 1.3 billion people, a polling station was set up in the middle of the jungle for one single man. (Ptaszynski)
A Canadian man who threw his speeding ticket out of his car window was then given a ticket for littering. (Schreiber)
The Moulin Rouge had a can-can dancer who would distract patrons by kicking off their hats, before promptly downing their drinks. (Harkin)
In 1959 as a publicity stunt a 3-ton block of ice was driven from the Arctic Circle to the equator. (Murray)
Prehistoric babies drank from animal-shaped sippy cups. (Ptaszynski)

The US Navy's "Doomsday aircraft", which was designed to survive a nuclear attack, was recently taken out by a single bird. (Harkin)

More than 80% of Japan's temples have suffered from raccoon damage. (Ptaszynski)

The first criminal in Boston to be sent to the stocks was the man who had built the stocks. He was found guilty of overcharging for the building of the stocks. (Schreiber)
Five of the main types of French baguette are called flute, ficelle, Viennois, sarmentine and bastard. (Murray)
Whitney Houston's record label once sent a cease and desist letter to Saddam Hussein asking him to stop using the song I Will Always Love You as part of his political campaign. (Ptaszynski)
In 1898 a Boston magazine described the game of croquet as "a source of slumbering depravity. a veritable Frankenstein's monster of recreation". (Harkin)
The star of the film Candyman, where a character has bees coming out of his mouth, negotiated a $1000 bonus for every time he got stung. He ended up with $23,000. (Murray)
As well using crash test dummies, Volvo tests its cars with a crash test moose. (Schreiber)
Americans used to make their slippers radioactive so they could find them in the dark. (Harkin)
The man who introduced chewing gum to the world had already been President of Mexico 11 times. (Ptaszynski)
Carl Sagan spent two years suing Apple Computers for calling him a butthead. (Schreiber)
In 1995, while in space, astronaut Bill Gregory ate 48 meals in a row which included shrimp cocktail. (Murray)
The loudest male birds on Earth use their voices to yell at females who are sat right next to them. (Harkin)

In the 1490s the Italians called syphilis "the French disease", the French called it "the Italian disease", the Russians called it "the Polish disease", the Polish called it "the Turkish disease", the Turkish called it "the Christian disease", and the Tahitians called it "the British disease". Actually, they should've all been calling it "the American disease". (Ptaszynski)
When racehorses travel by aeroplane they're allowed to bring an emotional support goat for no extra cost. (Harkin)

One of the main reasons people failed to get into the US Army in World War I was because they required recruits to have a minimum of six teeth. (Murray)
The Ronald Reagan Presidential Library has been protected from wildfires by a herd of goats that includes Vincent van Goat, Selena Goatmez, and Goatzart. (Ptaszynski)
The Apollo 12 moon landing footage was faked. (Schreiber)
Australian poppy fields have crop circles. They are caused by wallabies getting high and jumping around in circles. (Harkin)
The last TV show that the award-winning eminent physicist Heinz Oberhummer made before he passed away was called "The Universe Is A Shithole". (Schreiber)
Early laser eye surgery was performed in a trailer next to a trash compactor that, whenever it was switched on, would vibrate the trailer as the doctors were trying to operate. (Ptaszynski)
Some Inuit, if they got extremely hungry, would've been able to eat their own sleds. (Murray)
Some bottled water in Vienna costs €9000 per litre. (Harkin)
In 1958 the Queen's speech was lost on the day of delivery, and then found by a nearby poodle. (Murray)
As well as being the birthplace of Jesus, Bethlehem is where we found the oldest depiction of people having sex. (Ptaszynski)
The most likely time of year to have a heart attack is during a family Christmas gathering. (Schreiber)
Mariah Carey has three Christmas trees, one of which is decorated with pictures of herself. (Harkin)
In 1996 a windsurfer successfully broke into Alcatraz Prison while it was hosting the movie premier of The Rock, a film about people trying to break into Alcatraz. (Schreiber)
Horatio Nelson had a brother whose name was Suckling Nelson. (Murray)
In the 11th century hundreds of people in England paid their rent in eels. (Harkin)
According to Polynesian mythology, Māui, who is the god in the Disney film Moana, died by climbing into a goddess' vagina and being crushed to death by the obsidian teeth in there. (Ptaszynski)
In Britain alone, unnecessary emails create nearly 24,000 tons of carbon every year. (Murray)
Hot dogs are called hot dogs because people used to think they contained dog. (Harkin)
The oldest recording we have of a poet reading his own poem is of Robert Browning, who forgets the words to the poem halfway through and ends the recording with an apology. (Schreiber)
In 1948 in Idaho, leftover World War II parachutes were used to drop beavers out of aeroplanes. (Ptaszynski)
Thomas Edison was once almost killed by a flying badger. (Harkin)
There are only two groups of animals on Earth that live entirely on seaweed. They are a type of iguana and a type of sheep. (Ptaszynski)
In 2017 China launched the world's first electric cargo ship. The ship is now being used exclusively to transport coal to power stations. (Schreiber)
The first ever instrument made for food quality control was built to test the consistency of jelly. (Murray)
When the Greek government put a tax on swimming pools in 2008, only 324 Athenians admitted to having one. A search by Google Earth revealed the actual number to be 16,974. (Lloyd)
Some pterosaurs had heads that were more than four times the length of their bodies. (Ptaszynski)
The world's first casino had a rule that you could only gamble if you were wearing a tricorn hat. (Harkin)
To promote his new product, the inventor of Vaseline would demonstrate the invention by dipping his hands in acid and then healing the wounds with the balm.  (Schreiber)
After being stuck at an opera that went on twice as long as the scheduled running time, Emperor Joseph II of Austria banned encores. (Ptaszynski)
Humans have transported European earthworms to every continent on the planet except Antarctica, in a process some experts are calling 'global worming'. (Harkin)
The most popular street name in America is 'Second Street'. The second most popular is 'Third Street', and the third most popular is 'First Street'. (Schreiber)
The game of Scrabble is partly thanks to Edgar Allen Poe. (Murray)
Even the dust at GCHQ is classified. (Miller)
People drive more carefully if they have a pavlova in the car than their own child. (Murray)

Baby Albatrosses can take up to six days to peck their way out of their eggs. (Ptaszynski)
There is a 16th century exercise manual which recommends exercises such as running, tennis, and loud reading. (Murray)
Scientists in Georgia just blew a 6-metre-wide soap bubble. (Ptaszynski)

Before she became famous, Marilyn Monroe was named the "Artichoke Queen" of Castroville, California, "Miss Cheesecake" by Stars and Stripes magazine, and "Queen" of the Radioplane company where she worked assembling millitary drones during World War II. (Schreiber)
There is a salamander in Bosnia who hasn't moved from the same spot since 2010. (Harkin)
Travelling salesmen used to carry around miniature versions of everything they were selling. (Ptaszynski)
Female grizzly bears can get half-pregnant. (Murray)
When the Vandals sacked Rome in 455 AD, they agreed that they would just take the money and not damage any of the property. (Harkin)

People who have died from laughing include a 5th century Greek artist who couldn't stop laughing at his own painting, and an Australian dog trainer who died after reading the price difference of some commodities in 1915 as opposed to 1920. (Schreiber)
When the world's largest bottle of wine sprung a leak this year, the owner called the local fire department, who stopped the spillage with sandbags. (Harkin)

When Michelangelo sculpted David, the town mayor told him that the nose was too big, so Michelangelo picked up some dust, climbed to the top of the statue, sprinkled the dust down, and claimed that he had fixed it. (Ptaszynski)
A plane was once built which had nine wings. (Murray)
This year a sperm bank lost a court case to a man named Dick Weiner. (Schreiber)
Pompeii's 'new' drain system is 2300 years old. (Murray)

Researchers have 3D printed sex dolls for turtles. (Ptaszynski)
Computer pioneer Charles Babbage once cooked himself in an oven for 4 minutes at 265 degrees just to see what would happen. (Schreiber)

Cryonic freezing chambers are built to store up to 4 bodies and 5 heads. (Ptaszynski)
If Hamlet had wanted to buy a lemon, it would've cost him €700. (Murray)

Jessica Alba has ridden the London Eye thirty-one times. (Bell)

The first ever internal combustion engine was partially powered by explosive moss. (Murray)
We have arches in our feet for the same reason that we fold slices of pizza. (Ptaszynski)

In 2014 four non-related economists with the surname Goodman published a paper about the economics of surname-sharing. The paper was titled A Few Goodmen. (Schreiber)
If you wanted to have a bath in Paris in the 1820s, you could have one delivered to your door. (Ptaszynski)
Dogs can suffer from a sprained tail if they get too happy. (Harkin)
When people accidentally swallow coins, their stomachs sometimes punch holes in them. (Ptaszynski)
Soldiers in the Russian Army weren't issued socks until 2011. (Murray)
In 2016 a man won the lottery for the second time using the exact same numbers that won it for him the first time. That man's name is Larry Gambles. (Schreiber)
Zagreb has a museum of hangovers. Its inventor was inspired when a friend woke up one morning with an unexplained bike pedal in his pocket. (Harkin)
In 1825 Britain's most famous actor was nearly murdered by his own furious audience. (Jenner)
It wasn't until 1913 that we finally figured out how to stop our food tasting like our cutlery. (Ptaszynski)
Ants have a special stomach which is just to contain food to throw up into the mouths of other ants. (Murray)
Ancient Egyptians had artificial egg incubators, but they didn't have thermometers, so they measured the temperature of the eggs by holding them to their eyelids. (Harkin)
Loofahs are edible. (Ptaszynski)
The man who invented Jumanji did so because he hated Monopoly. (Miller)
There is a man in Brazil who nobody is allowed to go within 5 miles of. (Harkin)

In 1547 the Venetian government assassinated two men to stop them from revealing how mirrors were made. (Harkin)
The longest car in the world was so long that it had a literal backseat driver. (Schreiber)
Ancient British fruit varieties include the Hen's Turd Apple and the Bloody Bastard Pear. (Murray)
If you were to take a corn on the cob and remove each kernel in a row while saying "she loves me" and then "she loves me not", then she will always love you not. (Harkin)
Mayan gods include "flying scab", "gathered blood", and "pus demon". (Ptaszynski)

Hagfish can eat by sitting inside their dinner and absorbing the nutrients through their skin. (Harkin)
1982's Time Person of the Year was the personal computer. The article announcing it was written on a typewriter. (Schreiber)

In order to decide which direction to go and preach every day, Franciscans spun round and round until they were so dizzy that they fell over, and then went in whichever way their head was pointing. (Ptaszynski)
In 2004 a Canadian cheesemaker dropped $50,000 worth of cheese into a lake to make it taste better, but then lost the cheese. (Murray)

Early proposals for raising the Titanic back to the ocean's surface included filling it up with ping-pong balls, injecting 180,000 tonnes of vaseline into it, and turning the ship itself into an iceberg. (Schreiber)
In 1927 an owl was found that had another owl in its stomach, and that owl had a third owl in its stomach. (Harkin)

Sand dunes are brilliant at social distancing. (Schreiber)
According to a recent publication people from the North of England are more than twice as likely to be naturally funny than people from the South of England. (Harkin)
In 1943 German troops who were rescuing Mussolini had to seize control of a tourist funicular railway so they could ride a cable car to the top of a hill and pick him up. (Ptaszynski)
In Medieval Germany bad musicians were tied to an instrument called the flute of shame. (Murray)

Aladdin is Chinese. (Ptaszynski)
Merry-go-rounds were invented in medieval times for knights to ride on. (Schreiber)
In some parts of Japan earwigs are known as Chinpo-Kiri. Literally "penis cutters". (Harkin)
Two days after recieving his latest book the author of Annals of Gullibility: Why We Get Duped and How To Avoid It lost hundreds of thousands of dollars in a Ponzi scheme. (Schreiber)
In 2011 former paralympian Josh Sundquist, who's missing his left leg, announced that he'd found his solemate. i.e. someone missing a right leg with whom he can split pairs of shoes. (Ptaszynski)
You can now diagnose a urinary tract infection with a fidget spinner. (Murray)

Al Capone ran a soup kitchen during the Great Depression. He served beef on Thanksgiving in 1930 because there had just been a theft of 1,000 turkeys nearby and he didn't want the authorities to think it was him. (Harkin)
Spies can tell what people are saying by looking at the lights in the room they're in. (Murray)
London Bridge was destroyed by a tornado in 1091. (Harkin)
This year's Dutch national Headwind championships were cancelled during the race because it was too windy. (Schreiber)
Every week planes drop 50 million flies on the border between Colombia and Panama. (Ptaszynski)
The London Underground used to have a church interval on sundays. (Schreiber)
The first ice cream on a stick was called the Good Humor Bar. It was a modified version of a lollipop caleld the Jolly Boy Sucker. (Harkin)
Kublai Khan's summer palace could be dismantled and folded away at the end of every summer. (Ptaszynski)
According to the people who have drunk it, billion-year-old water tastes terrible. (Murray)
Before hermit crabs were called hermit crabs there was a hermit called Crab. (Schreiber)
The Magna Carta smells of newly pressed sheets with traces of old socks. (Harkin)
Ford has a car wash made of giant ostrich feather dusters. (Murray)
According to Kellogg's, Tony the Tiger is an adult cartoon. (Ptaszynski)
Golden moles shine in all the colours of the rainbow and they'll never know it. (Ptaszynski)
Mozart and Beethoven both composed music for an instrument made entirely of glass. It was invented by Benjamin Franklin. (Schreiber)
Envelopes used to be made of clay. (Murray)
In 1939 America made a huge vehicle to drive across Antarctica. Unfortunately they put no tread on the tyres so it couldn't drive across the ice. (Harkin)
The Holy Roman Emperor once made every citizen of Milan pluck a fig from a mule's genitals with their teeth. (Ptaszynski)
Library books can set on fire if you put them in a microwave. (Harkin)
One of the Kings of León was called Alfonso the Slobberer. (Murray)
There is a Chinese poem made up of 92 characters in which every word is pronounced "shi". The poem is called "Lion-Eating Poet in the Stone Den" or "Shī-shì shí shī shǐ". (Schreiber)
In the 18th century women expressed their political beliefs by wearing decorative stickers on their faces. (Ptaszynski)
The very first print run of The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn had to be pulped after a bookstore owner discovered someone had sneaked a drawing of a penis into one of the illustrations. (Schreiber)
Before vaccination was invented the main method of inoculation against smallpox was to powder scabs and blow them up your nose. (Murray)
You can tell if a movie character is a goodie or a baddie by the kind of phone they use. (Harkin)
In 1948 a drive-through fly-through cinema opened in New Jersey, where you could watch movies from the seat of your car or the seat of your small aircraft. (Harkin)
The Beatles once rejected a £50m reunion gig because the warm-up act was going to be a man wrestling a great white shark. (Schreiber)

In 1919 it was ruled that women would be allowed to swim competitively without wearing stockings on the one condition that they quickly put on a robe as soon as they got out of the water. (Ptaszynski)
The filming of Doctor Dolittle was delayed for days after the giraffe being used accidentally stepped on its own penis. (Murray)
Sloane Square underground station has a river running through it. (Toksvig)
In 1992 Hoover ran a promotion which was so successful that the firm collapsed and had to be sold off. (Murray)
After he retired from dancing in his late 70s, Fred Astaire became a skateboarder. (Schreiber)
The Icelandic word for a museum is the same as the word for a flock of sheep. (Harkin)
For 15 years German police hunted a serial killer who didn't exist. (Pascoe)
To run a Boeing 747 you need a binder full of floppy disks. (Murray)
In the 1920 US Election, which was the first after women got the vote in America, only one woman in the whole of Georgia managed to cast a vote. (Harkin)

In 1801, England had a celebrity ox which had its own coach and horses. (Murray)
The world's least frequently published newspaper is released once every four years on leap day. The print edition costs €4.70, or you can subscribe to it for €100 per century. (Schreiber)

One theory of the origin of the nursery rhyme Pussy Cat Pussy Cat is that it's a reference to Queen Anne's poor personal hygeine and an accumulation of grime that once fell out of her skirt during a service at St Paul's Cathedral. (Ryan)
In 1862 there was a special cravat invented to stop people strangling you in the street. (Murray)
For 24 years any ship travelling between Wellington and Nelson in New Zealand would be guided through the most dangerous section by a dolphin called Pelorus Jack. (Harkin)
The estate of Arthur Conan Doyle is currently suing Netflix for showing Sherlock Holmes as having feelings and respecting women. (Schreiber)
Tom Scott wanted to make a YouTube video about how interesting strobe lighting is, but the likelihood was that it would give one of his viewers an epileptic fit. (Scott)
From the 1880s until 1927 Paris had an underground clock system which ran on puffs of air. (Murray)
After a penguin had to be isolated due to health issues, zookeepers in Perth are keeping him entertained by letting him binge-watch Pingu. (Harkin)
The person who measured the world's tallest tree did so by climbing to the top of it and dropping a tape measure down. (Ptaszynski)
Along with their drink, New Yorkers in bars used to be served a sandwich full of rubber. (Murray)
Dead fish can swim upstream. (Ptaszynski)

There is a stone marker in Wisconsin which commemorates the spot where Elvis Presley once successfully stopped a fight by jumping out of his limo, pulling some karate moves, and threatening to kick everyone's ass. (Schreiber)
In 1943 a spy who topped the Gestapo's most-wanted list was New Zealander Nancy Wake, who once judo-chopped a Nazi to death. (Darby)
John Cleese's silly walk is exactly 6.7 times sillier than a normal walk. (Harkin)
In 1814 there were days of rioting in Dublin because a dog that was supposed to be starring in a play failed to show up on stage. (Ptaszynski)

While filming Return of the Jedi in the forests of California, the actor who played Chewbacca had to be accompanied by crew members in brightly-coloured vests so that he wasn't shot by Bigfoot hunters. (Schreiber)

Theodore Roosevelt was once shot in the chest but survived thanks to a 50-page-long speech tucked into his coat pocket. He delivered the speech reading from pages that now had two bullet holes in them. (Schreiber)

In 2017 the US Defense Secretary had a light installed in his bathroom which would turn on if North Korea launched a nuclear missile. (Murray)

Fashion historian Hilary Davidson has invented the Bill & Ted Test, which judges the historical accuracy of movie costumes by comparing them against the surprisingly accurate movie Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure. (Harkin)
In India you automatically get a government job if you qualify for the Olympics, and if you win a medal you get a promotion. (Ptaszynski)
The photo of the Wright brothers' first flight was taken by a man who had never used a camera before. (Schreiber)
On the French island of Île de Ré the donkeys wear trousers. (Harkin)
In the late 1960s, the CIA considered assassinating people using lightning. (Murray)
In the 1930s, the ghost of a swearing mongoose led the BBC to revise its working conditions. (Ptaszynski)
Famous occultist Aleister Crowley used to make a curry so hot that he only served it on glaciers, so that diners could use the snow to cool their mouth down afterwards. (Harkin)
Japan's yakuza have been told they are no longer allowed to join in trick-or-treating. (Schreiber)
Ghost crabs use teeth in their stomachs to growl at their enemies. (Murray)
When you do a spacewalk, you have to wear 16 layers of clothing and a nappy. (Peake)

Chicago has an alcoholic spirit which tastes so bad that its own founder used to boast that only 1 in 49 men liked it. (Murray)
Land Rover once released a manual which was edible, so if you got lost in the desert you could eat it to survive. (Schreiber)
In 1978 chess player Viktor Korchnoi accused Anatoly Karpov of cheating using an elaborate yoghurt-based code. (Harkin)
Immitators of Harry Houdini included Howdyni, Boudini, Oudini, Howdini, Hoedini, Hardini, Houdeen, Bernardi, and Cunning the Jailbreaker. (Murray)

One of Hawaii's biggest annual festivals is devoted entirely to Spam. (Schreiber)

Sir Roger Penrose, the mathematician who's just won the Nobel Prize, once designed a theoretically infinite geometrical pattern called the Penrose tiles. He then sued a toilet paper company for stealing it and creating a theoretically infinite toilet paper roll. (Murray)
Washington State's Department of Agriculture recently lost track of the single hornet they were trying to follow. (Ptaszynski)
2 years after the release of the first James Bond movie, an actual British spy called James Bond was discovered in Poland. (Harkin)

In 1970, burglars managed to successfully get past an unpickable door lock and steal American government documents by tapping a note to it a few hours beforehand that read "Please don't lock this door tonight". (Schreiber)

In 1997, a mass tug of war went so badly wrong that it ripped two of the contestants' arms off. (Ptaszynski)

In medieval elections, you were supposed to object to any suggestion that you wanted to win. When he became Archbishop of Canterbury in 1093, Saint Anselm refused to accept the ceremonial staff, so they had to break his fingers to force it into his hand. (Harkin)
The reason America has a national anthem is down to Robert Ripley, believe it or not. (Schreiber)
From the Lismore Library in Australia you can borrow a person. (Davies)
It's illegal in the UK to tickle a trout. (Ptaszynski)
All of the cheese eaten on Antarctica is past its expiration date. (Harkin)
In 1990, a British Airways flight landed with one pilot in the cockpit and the other hanging by his legs outside the front window. (Schreiber)
1 in 3 people in the UK has seen the Queen in real life. (Murray)

In 1714, when a Dutch ship ran out of ammunition 14 hours into a battle, the captain sent a boat over to the enemy asking to borrow some gunpowder and cannonballs so they could continue the fight. (Schreiber)
Vanilla farmers in Madagascar stamp their names on each individual pod on the vine. (Ptaszynski)
Russian football team FC Sakhalin are based in such a remote town that, to get to their closest away game, they have to travel 1/6 of the circumference of the Earth. (Harkin)
There is such a big market for fake letters by Abraham Lincoln that people have started selling fake fakes. (Murray)
If you ask someone what day it is, they'll take twice as long to answer on a Wednesday as they would on a Monday or Friday. (Harkin)

When hosting parties, singer Dean Martin would sometimes ring the police pretending to be an angry neighbour so that they would ask his guests to go home, instead of him.[3] (Andrew Hunter Murray)
Caves in Tasmania include: Poo Shooter Cave, Itchy Hole, Horrible Accident Cave, and Dead Horse Cave, which was named because at the bottom of it they found the remains of a cow.[4] (James Harkin)

In the 1920 Winter Olympics, US skater Theresa Weld was the only woman in the figure skating who performed jumps, but she was marked down every time she did because her skirt rose above her knees, which was considered too scandalous.[1] (James Harkin)
In the early 1900s, the US government installed telephones at the top of trees.[2] (Anna Ptaszynski)
There is a worm which can grow multiple bottoms which it then fires off to have sex without it.[3] (Andrew Hunter Murray)
Comedian Lenny Bruce was arrested so often during his sets that he would go on stage wearing his coat just so he was ready to leave with the police immediately.[4] (Dan Schreiber)
Logs used to be carried around the Andaman Islands by swimming elephants.[1] (Anna Ptaszynski)
There is a French parliamentary manoeuvre which involves MPs hiding behind a curtain and then bursting out to vote at the last minute.[2] (Andrew Hunter Murray)
One of the biggest theme parks in China has a ride that puts visitors in a coffin, rolls them into a chamber, and then simulates their cremation.[3] (Dan Schreiber)
The actor Peter O'Toole once smuggled a pair of earrings out of Greece by hiding them in his foreskin.[4] (James Harkin)

In 1939, a young doctor at Boston City Hospital went on a scurvy-producing diet to see what would happen. In May 1940, his fellow doctors staged an intervention after his skin started to bleed from his follicles and an old post-operative scar reopened.[1] (Tim Harford)
There are more people alive today who have been World Chess Champion than there are people skillful enough to carve a knight for use in a World Championship chess match.[2][3] (James Harkin)
In Ecuador, "cleaners" are people who rub you down with stinging nettles.[4] (Anna Ptaszynski)

The people of the remote island of St Kilda used to yell if they saw themselves in a visiting tourist's mirror. They actually had plenty of mirrors, they just wanted to keep the tourists coming.[5] (Andrew Hunter Murray)
In 1954, Derbyshire Cricket Club tried drying out its pitch with a jet engine.[1] (Andrew Hunter Murray)
There's currently a court case going on in Ireland about whether stained glass windows are actually windows.[2] (Anna Ptaszynski)
Hard Rock Cafe is owned globally by a group of Native Americans.[3] (Dan Schreiber)

When female seals have sex, they have a special muscle in their vagina that can clamp around their partner to stop sea water from getting in. That means that in order to create a seal, they first need to create a seal.[4] (James Harkin)
There was a job in the 19th century which just involved looking at the sea and being able to tell when there were pilchards under the surface.[1] (Andrew Hunter Murray)
The sound designer for the movie King Richard is called Richard King.[2] (Dan Schreiber)
There is a tree in Pakistan that has been under arrest for more than 120 years.[3] (James Harkin)
Pad thai was invented as part of a fascist government initiative.[4] (Anna Ptaszynski)
